dialogue_line_replacements.text: Desayuno a las ocho. Suelo tomar un café con tostadas.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: I have breakfast at eight. I usually have a coffee with toast.

dialogue_line_replacements.text: Salgo a las nueve menos cuarto. Voy al trabajo en metro.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: I leave at quarter to nine. I go to work by tube.

dialogue_line_replacements.text: Normalmente me acuesto a las doce. Leo un poco antes de dormir.
dialogue_line_replacements.translation: I normally go to bed at midnight. I read a bit before sleeping.

cultural_notes_overrides.formality: Spanish daily routines run significantly later than in the UK or US: breakfast 8–9am, lunch 2–3pm (the main meal), dinner 9–11pm. 'El aperitivo' (pre-lunch drink and snacks) is common on weekends.
cultural_notes_overrides.gestures: Yawning and stretching when talking about waking up is universal. In Spain, people often mime coffee-drinking when discussing morning routines.
cultural_notes_overrides.regional_variations: 'La siesta' is less common in modern urban Spain than the stereotype suggests — most working people take a lunch break but not a formal nap. However, shops still close 2–5pm in many towns.
cultural_notes_overrides.distincion: 'Acostarse' [akosˈtaɾse] vs 'despertarse' [despeɾˈtaɾse] — no /θ/ issue in these verbs, but 'almorzar' [almoɾˈθaɾ] features the Castilian /θ/ in the stem.
